evolution_stages.conversation_summary: 1) PROBLEMS: Jamie exhibited severe networking anxiety (shaking hands, panic over LinkedIn responses), career-search paralysis (rewriting resume endlessly), and physical/cognitive strain from poor time management (12-hour coding sessions). 2) SOLUTIONS: Coach provided templated LinkedIn message, scheduled 'human being hours', broke outreach into micro-steps (draft→schedule→reward), and introduced spreadsheet tracking for remote jobs. 3) RESPONSE: Jamie accepted all solutions - set 9am calendar reminder for messaging, created job-tracking spreadsheet, scheduled posture breaks, and committed to Friday progress email. 4) PROGRESS: Demonstrated measurable behavioral changes including calendar blocking for self-care, adopting low-pressure outreach tactics, and reframing networking as 'showing up imperfectly' rather than requiring perfection.

1) Problems discussed: Networking paralysis (fear of rejection), perfectionism in projects, and physical/mental burnout from overwork. 2) Solutions offered/accepted: Templated LinkedIn outreach with scheduled send time; reframing networking as 'making CS friends'; accepting work-in-progress sharing; scheduled breaks with rewards. 3) Student's response: Initially hesitant but engaged in solution-building (co-created messages, scheduled actions, participated in roleplay). Demonstrated self-awareness by identifying perfectionism. 4) Evidence of progress: Calendar entries for concrete actions (Friday message send, Thursday breaks); developed coping strategy (reward system); completed anxiety-provoking roleplay; drafted proactive follow-up plan.

Conversation analysis unavailable - fallback materialization used

Discussed Jamie's severe networking anxiety and perfectionism blocking job search. Solutions: 1) Graduated exposure to networking (drafted/scheduled templated LinkedIn message) 2) Reframing imperfect projects as learning opportunities 3) Structured time management ('human hours'). Jamie showed progress by: accepting message template, scheduling send time with reward system (coffee), identifying perfectionism patterns, blocking break times, and developing authentic project explanations. Demonstrated increased self-awareness through humor ('AWS Instance Assassin') and commitment to incremental steps despite ongoing anxiety.

Discussed Jamie's job search anxiety and networking paralysis. Solutions: 1) Structured alumni outreach approach (template + scheduling + reward system) 2) Reframing networking as 'making CS friends' 3) Project pitching techniques focusing on specific achievements. Jamie responded positively: Created send schedule, drafted messages, and practiced pitches despite discomfort. Progress evidenced by: Scheduled first outreach, developed elevator pitch, implemented anxiety buffers (coffee reward, coding distraction), and set family call reminder. Perfectionism addressed through 'show one polished element' strategy.
